story:
MAS: dba La Comunidad and Art for the Heart (MAS=Mountain Ambulance Service, a 501(c)3), is our fiscal agent.  Your donation will go to MAS, whose mission is the health and wellness of our community.  It will only be used for Celebracion de Culturas (ie: entertainment, publicity, venue rental and other expenses related to the event).  We are all volunteers, and need your help to make this an annual event.

We're having a festival.  We need your contribution;  and we want you to join us!

June 12th, 13th and 14th, this summer is when it's happening.

Celebracion de Culturas  Aquí Estamos :  Cha on ii phoha ee : We are Here : Family y Tradiciones

Here's what's happening:
  • Friday evening kickoff @ The Penasco Theatre, 5pm - Dinner, Dance with Cipriano Vigil, and Honoring of our Ancianos.
  • Saturday morning @ Picuris Pueblo, 10am - San Antonio Feast Day footraces. 
  • Saturday evening @ The Penasco Theatre, 7pm - Poetry Reading by Levi Romero, NM Centennial Poet Laureate from Embudo Valley plus others.
  • Saturday and Sunday 10-5 @ The Penasco Theatre, Presentations of Genealogy, Histories, Stories and Photograhs
  • Saturday and Sunday 10-5  Demonstrations of Tradtional Skills and Practices at locations throughout Penasco and surrounding areas.  Maps will be available. 

The Impact

The festival will enhance community pride, and help the local economy.  Your contribution will help us market all over the state of New Mexico. and will make the festival a big success.

Annual Event

To make this an annual event, we need your donation now; and we need volunteers to begin planning next year's event.  More info email: penasconm@gmail.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our fundraiser and event by sharing this on email and social media.  Indiegogo has share tools that make it easy.
story_txt:
MAS: dba La Comunidad and Art for the Heart (MAS=Mountain Ambulance Service, a 501(c)3), is our fiscal agent.  Your donation will go to MAS, whose mission is the health and wellness of our community.  It will only be used for Celebracion de Culturas (ie: entertainment, publicity, venue rental and other expenses related to the event).  We are all volunteers, and need your help to make this an annual event.
We're having a festival.  We need your contribution;  and we want you to join us!
June 12th, 13th and 14th, this summer is when it's happening.
Celebracion de Culturas  Aquí Estamos :  Cha on ii phoha ee : We are Here : Family y Tradiciones
Here's what's happening:


Friday evening kickoff @ The Penasco Theatre, 5pm - Dinner, Dance with Cipriano Vigil, and Honoring of our Ancianos.

Saturday morning @ Picuris Pueblo, 10am - San Antonio Feast Day footraces. 

Saturday evening @ The Penasco Theatre, 7pm - Poetry Reading by Levi Romero, NM Centennial Poet Laureate from Embudo Valley plus others.

Saturday and Sunday 10-5 @ The Penasco Theatre, Presentations of Genealogy, Histories, Stories and Photograhs

Saturday and Sunday 10-5  Demonstrations of Tradtional Skills and Practices at locations throughout Penasco and surrounding areas.  Maps will be available. 

   
The Impact

 The festival will enhance community pride, and help the local economy.  Your contribution will help us market all over the state of New Mexico. and will make the festival a big success.
    Annual Event To make this an annual event, we need your donation now; and we need volunteers to begin planning next year's event.  More info email: penasconm@gmail.com.
    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word about our fundraiser and event by sharing this on email and social media.  Indiegogo has share tools that make it easy.

story:
$10,000 Can Provide All Expenses Needed for 5 Poor Children to Attend School for a Year!

For only $2,000 per year we can provide a full scholarship for one child including all tuition and fees, school uniforms, shoes, books, book bags, all school supplies, school activities and meals including breakfast and lunch! This campaign will provide 5 of these scholarships to start, but it doesn't stop there. For every $2,000 dollars we raise, we will add an additional scholarship.  All money received goes directly to helping poor children attend school.

Over 13 Million Children Living in Poverty

The Philippines has over 13 million children who are living in poverty. Millions of these children will have little chance of going to school and getting an education. Education is one of the country’s main problems that needs to be addressed in order to reduce the ever growing rate of poverty.

At Teaching Kids to Fish we believe in that proverb and have made it our goal to help children get a quality education that will allow them to succeed in life.  By doing so we are able to change the lives of not only these children but also their families, truly feeding them for life!

The Story of 7 Year-Old Bayani

Bayani wakes up before the sun rises, gets dressed, and finds a small bowl on the table, half full with cold white rice – his breakfast.   He walks out of the makeshift house made from discarded tin, wood, and plastic tarps. It is the only home Bayani has ever known.

As the sun rises, Bayani grabs a sack and hurries off to the garbage dump and to roam the streets around his home looking for things he can collect to earn a little money. 

He passes a school and pauses to watch the children laughing and talking as they enter the school grounds in their neat uniforms. The school children see Bayani, but ignore him. He is not like them; he is dirty and poor.

He wipes tears away from his face as he walks away. He wants to go to school but he can’t. At the age of 7, he must help support his family by collecting plastic bottles, cardboard, or anything else that can be recycled. If he can collect enough, he will help his mom buy another small bag of rice so they will have food to eat for another day. Bayani is one of the statistics. He is one out every four children in the Philippines who lives in poverty.

Bayani will walk the streets as far as 2 miles from his home. The sun is hot and he knows it is noon, not just because the sun is high in the sky, but because his stomach is growling and hurts. He continues to pick up plastic bottles as he is going through the garbage of a local restaurant. He finds some tasty treasures for his lunch, food that the restaurant customers did not fully eat.

Half-eaten chicken leg, pieces of a pork, half-eaten spring rolls, he hit the jackpot and is able to feed his hunger until the growling and hurt in his stomach are gone.   Bayani finds a plastic bag and starts to dig in another garbage container from the next restaurant. He finds a chicken breast with only a small bite taken out of it, six pieces of shrimp, a piece of beef, some boiled potatoes, and some carrots. He will be able to take this home to feed his pregnant mom and 4 year old brother. 

He finds some plastic bottles and other trash that he puts in his sack of items to be recycled. His mom will buy some rice with the 47 pesos (about $1) he got from his recyclable collection over the last two days. 

Bayani is a Filipino name that means hero. Today, Bayani is a hero, but only for one evening because he has to go out and do it again tomorrow, and the next day, and the next, and the next until he is old enough to leave home and go out on his own.

Today was a good day for this little 7 year old hero. Bayani’s mother loves him and knows that the way out of poverty is for him to go to school but she does not know how she can help him to do it. Unless he is provided with the opportunity to go to school, Bayani will just stay another statistic.

38% of the Children in the Philippines will Receive Minimal or No Education in 2015

Poverty in the Philippines continues to rise despite the recent progress in the country’s economy. More families suffer from lack of income and job opportunities, disabling them to support their children’s education which leads to the increasing percentage of school dropouts. The saddest fact is more children will not have the chance to get basic education.

Percent of Undereducated Children *

The proportion of working children who will receive a minimal or no education

* Child poverty in the Philippines, Philippine Institute for Development Studies. Read The Report..

Despite High Economic Growth, Poverty in the Philippines is on the Rise

Although Asia as a region has been successful in translating positive economic growth to poverty reduction, Philippine poverty is still increasing despite its growing GDP. Read More.

8 Year-Old Mirasol Wants to be a Teacher

Mirasol, whose name means sunflower, is a beautiful little girl who lives up to her name. She has jet black hair, straight and dirty, that would be pretty if it were combed and the lice were washed out. Her eyes are coal black and look as if they could command the sun to rise, if they only had the sparkle of a happy eight year old girl. Instead, her eyes are sad and scared. Her face is smudged with dirt, old and worn-out clothes hang from her skinny body She walks barefooted, not seeming to notice the hot asphalt or rocks.

She follows her mother carrying her baby sister and her 4 year old brother. It is rush hour and time to beg for whatever coins they can get. It is illegal to beg and illegal to give money to beggars, but that is a law that is seldom enforced.

At the intersection, the traffic light turns red and Marisol has to go to work tapping on car windows and putting on her saddest, hungriest look, hoping someone will give her just a coin or two so that her mom will have money to feed them tonight. The window of her first car comes down and a young boy hands her a half-eaten hamburger. She thanks the boy and brings it to her mother to divide between her brother and sister. She taps on one more window before the light turns to green, an elderly man puts his hand out the window and gives our Sunflower three coins totaling 16 pesos. Marisol manages a smile and a thank you as the man drives away. She runs to her mother and gives her the money. A good start for Marisol, a half-eaten hamburger and 16 pesos (about 34 cents) before breakfast.

Her mother pushes Marisol to go back to the traffic and continue begging until the rush hour is over. Another hour of work and she is able to give her mother only 3 pesos.

There will be no breakfast for our wilting Sunflower this day. The look in her eyes are sadder and hungrier.

After the morning rush, Mirasol sits against a post on the side of the road, exhausted and hungry. She falls into a restless sleep until she is shaken awake by her mother and told to get back to work. Looking at a passing school service, she knows she will never have the opportunity to go to school to be a teacher, or doctor, or just Mirasol with a future.

Mirasol begins to cry as she approaches the first car of the lunch break. Mirasol looks at a middle-aged lady who tries to comfort her, but all the kind words will not help our little Sunflower blossom. Mirasol looks at the lady and says, “I cannot go to school.” The lady reaches over and pulls two ten peso coins out of her purse and hands them to Mirasol just as the light turns green and she speeds off. Mirasoljust stares in the direction the car drove. She is brought back to reality, from a daydream of a better life, by a slap on the back of her lice infected head by her mother who quickly grabs the two ten peso coins.

The day will soon come to an end with our wilted Sunflower exhausted and barely able to make it back to their one room squatter’s shack. Before her mother dishes up a bowl of cold rice, Mirasol has already curled up in her filthy blanket and is sound asleep, dreaming of a better life, of going to school.

This evening her dreams are filled with being a teacher and teaching her students how to be kind and to help all the hungry children of the world go to school.

The Problem with Education in the Philippines

Public education in the Philippines suffers from many other problems including overcrowded classrooms, lack of desks and chairs, lack of books and supplies and a shortage of teachers. We have seen classrooms designed for 20 students holding more than 50 in sweltering hot conditions. Lack of classrooms have lead many schools to try to hold 2 or even 3 class session in a single day, greatly shortening the learning time for the students.

Overcrowded classrooms and lack of school desks are the common problems in elementary schools nationwide.

This is why TKTF has teamed up with AILA to provide a complete solution. Our scholarships provide education in a top, international quality environment, with everything a student needs including books, supplies, uniforms and even nourishing meals. Some of these things may seem small but without uniforms, for example, these students would not have adequate school clothes. And without getting good nourishing meals, they will have a hard time to concentrate and to excel. If we are going to break the cycle of poverty, we need to have graduates who are given the opportunity to succeed in life.

Filipino children driven to the streets by crushing poverty

The American International Learning Academy

AILA is a private school located in Pampanga Philippines, just outside the former US Air Force base known as Clark. The school was founded three years ago by several American expats and their families to provide quality education for local students by combining American, Philippine, and other international standards and programs. The school is approved to operate and is licensed by the Philippines Department of Education (DepEd).

The goal of AILA has always been to be a part of the local community and to give back with livelihood programs and scholarships to allow anyone to have an opportunity to succeed. The owners and board members have funded more than 30 scholarships with their own money. All proceeds from the school are reinvested in the school or the local community.

About the Scholarships

We decided to start this crowdfunding campaign so that we could help even more students get the education they deserve and help take a small step in fighting the cycle of poverty. The scholarships include everything the student needs to attend and be successful in school including tuition, uniforms, books, supplies, school lunches, and health exams.

100% of all money received from this campaign will go directly to support scholarships! No admin costs, overhead costs or extra expenses are taken from the donations. Your contribution will go directly to a needy student.

Our first goal is to raise $10,000 which will provide scholarships to 5 needy children.  This represents 50% of the tuition and the cost of uniforms, books, supplies, school lunches, and health exams. The remainder of the tuition will be covered by AILA as our continued contribution to support this cause.

Here are the scholars you will be supporting:

Once we reach this goal, we will choose another 5 scholars. We hope that we will be able to provide 20 or more additional scholarships this school year.

Stretch Goals

After our initial goal of $10,000, additional funds will be used to provide more scholarships. If we raise:

Here are few of our additional potential scholars:

If your generosity allows to raise more than $100,000, we add to our existing facilities and consider opening another location to support more students. Some of the ideas we have are:

Classroom Expansion/ Technology

School Buses and Transportation

Land for new school

School Building

Provide Technology
for Remote Schools

Rest assured, whatever we raise will go directly to supporting education for poor and needy children.

Perks

100% of your donations will go directly to providing the needs of a scholarship student. With that in mind, we have chosen to provide more meaningful perks that are produced by the children, teachers and faculty to say thank you for your generous contributions.

As a supporter, you will receive a monthly newsletter so you can follow how your donation is making a difference in the lives of the children.

Receive a class picture of the students you helped support via e-mail and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

One of the scholarship recipients will send you a personal letter through e-mail to share with you their learning and experiences from the scholarship you helped provide. You will also receive a class picture and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

One of our scholars will create a unique piece of artwork and we will send it to you through e-mail as a small gift of gratitude to your kindness. You will also receive a class picture and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

Full Scholarship Paid Monthly
Support a full scholarship with an easy monthly donation and you will receive a video message from the scholar and with the parents thanking you for your commitment to help them get a better education. You will also receive a class picture and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

Half Scholarship
With this amount, you are providing half of a scholarship for a student. To thank you, you will receive a personal letter and a picture from the scholar you are supporting and we will send you quarterly updates from the scholar throughout the school year. You will also receive a class picture and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

Full Scholarship
With this donation, you are providing a full scholarship for a child. As a gratitude, you will receive a video message from the scholar and family directly thanking you for your help. We will also send you quarterly updates from the scholar throughout the school year and you will receive a class picture and be subscribed to our monthly newsletter.

We will be adding your name to our list of supporters that will be shown on our website on our supporter online plaque. (Let us know if you do not wish to have your name included.)

If you are inspired by these children, we would love to have you as part of our team. Email us at volunteer@teachingkidstofish.com and ask about how you can help as a volunteer here in the Philippines or back home. Let us know your background and interests and we will match you with opportunities where you can help the most.

If you are interested in larger corporate or tax exempt support of our mission, please send us an email as well.

Your Team in Fighting Poverty Through Education

Our team of educators and businessmen are involved in different charity works. With collective efforts we have taken small steps to move families out of poverty by providing quality education and with your help, more families will have the chance to improve their lives in the future.

We started the Teaching Kids to Fish Program to help in the process of eliminating poverty in the Philippines. Our goal is to provide financial assistance to children who otherwise will not be able to finish their education.

Mike Shane, President TKTF

We are doing this because we want to offer families a better life for the future. As educators we believe that in order to get out of poverty, we need to offer a quality education.

James Franson, Headmaster - AILA

Each one of us should take the commitment to help in any way we can. We are thankful that we help give a little hope to these deserving children.

Crispin Guintu, Partner - AILA

We are committed to helping children get access to better education. With your donations more children will have a chance to reach for their dreams and provide a better future for their families.

Claudia Guzman, Partner - AILA

Corporate Sponsors

When I saw the need for a better education for the poor, I did not think twice to support this campaign. I believe that this is the best way to give these children better lives.

Boris Prager

Vice President

This is indeed the right thing to do, help people by teaching them to help themselves. I am glad to be part this initiative and will continue to support it so that many children will have a better future.

Bless Serrano

Manager

This campaign moved me. Touching the lives of innocent kids by giving them the chance of a brighter future is really heartwarming.

Paul Lee

Founder

As a digital agency, we build brands. We are pleased that we were able to work on this campaign with TKTF and as a result have been able to help build lives. We have seen what a difference a little can make in the lives of these children and we are happy that we have been a part of it.

Noel Denola

Creative Director

We are doing this because we want to offer families a better life for the future. As educators we believe that in order to get out of poverty, we need to offer a quality education.
James Franson,  Headmaster - AILA











Each one of us should take the commitment to help in any way we can. We are thankful that we help give a little hope to these deserving children.
Crispin Guintu, Partner - AILA











We are committed to helping children get access to better education. With your donations more children will have a chance to reach for their dreams and provide a better future for their families.
Claudia Guzman, Partner - AILA







Corporate Sponsors
When I saw the need for a better education for the poor, I did not think twice to support this campaign. I believe that this is the best way to give these children better lives.









Boris Prager
Vice President







This is indeed the right thing to do, help people by teaching them to help themselves. I am glad to be part this initiative and will continue to support it so that many children will have a better future.









Bless Serrano
Manager







This campaign moved me. Touching the lives of innocent kids by giving them the chance of a brighter future is really heartwarming.









Paul Lee
Founder







As a digital agency, we build brands. We are pleased that we were able to work on this campaign with TKTF and as a result have been able to help build lives. We have seen what a difference a little can make in the lives of these children and we are happy that we have been a part of it.









Noel Denola
Creative Director

story:
The Gobi Gallop

The Longest Charity Ride on the Planet!
(For tax deductible donations, consider donating on the official Gobi Gallop fundraising site here: http://raiseathon.ca/gobigallop3)

Started in 2013 by the Veloo Foundation, the Gobi Gallop is a 700+ kilometer trek across the Mongolian countryside to raise funds for the Children of the Peak Sanctuary Project. This year, we will ride from central Mongolia to the border of Siberia, June 8th to June 19th.

(The Saddle is made of wood. 700 kilometers. On wood.) 

Children of the Peak Sanctuary is founded and run by Julie Veloo, the founder of the Veloo Foundation. She started the foundation after she moved to Mongolia, and saw the large number of families, including young children, living in and around garbage dumps in the city. Many were homeless and searching for food in the trash in -40* weather in winter. 
Poverty in Mongolia is directly connected to the relocation of nomads moving to the capital city of Ulaanbaatar. Men and women who have been raised in the countryside, living off of animal husbandry, possess extraordinary skills, but changes in the country's economy have made nomadism an increasingly unstable livelihood. Nomadic skills do not translate well to urban life, and just as us city-slickers wouldn't last one week in the Mongolian steppe by ourselves, so too do these people have great difficulty building lives for themselves in the city. 
For more information, please watch Julie's Ted Talk.

Children of the Peak Sanctuary functions as a safe place where homeless and disadvantaged children living on garbage dumps in urban Mongolia can receive primary school education, warm meals, and loving care. The children receive 2 meals and 2 snacks a day, a heated building in which to study, and a safe, secure play area. 

Further development plans include:
  1.  a hot water shower for the community (most people working on the garbage dump are turned away from the current community shower because they are "too dirty")
  2. another kindergarten building with three rooms and an additional kitchen
  3. an after-school homework assistance program for older children with little or no parental support 
  4. a school bus to enable more children to attend the school
  5. a local laundry to clean the children's and parent's clothing
You can find out more about the Veloo Foundation here. 

Costs

Each participant of the Gobi Gallop must raise at least $3200 US. Of this, riders pay $1600 to our expert guides and horsemen, Baggii and Saraa, to care for the horses and pay for our food/tents/gifts to people we meet along the way. The other $1600, raised by charity, and any additional funds, go directly to the Children of the Peak Sanctuary. 

Baggii and Saraa are extremely accomplished and conscientious caretakers of their animals. The horses' health and wellbeing is the top priority. Having visited their home and ridden their animals many times, I can say with absolute confidence that I have rarely seen such beloved animals, or extraordinary horsemanship. They make their living with their animals, and the money they earn helping us with the Gallop goes a long way to protecting their livelihood in the countryside. 

Your Donation

I have already paid, out of pocket, $2500 US, in order to secure my place in the Gallop. However, as a poor graduate student, this is above my means (I paid on my credit card). 

Therefore, I am looking to reimburse myself $900 (so my own donation is the original $1600, plus your $900 donation), and to raise at least an addition $1100, to be given straight to the charity. 

This works out to:

Christine pays $1600 for Baggii, Saraa, and the horses (out of her measly graduate student grants! How generous!)

Christine fundraises $900 for the Children of the Sanctuary Project (to reimburse her already-contributed $900, which she shouldn't have paid in the first place, and can't afford, but was so excited she ticked the wrong box). 

Christine fundraises an addition $1100 for the Children of the Sanctuary Project (because her friends are awesome, the kids are worth it, and she knows we can do it!)


How You Can Help

Please consider donating to this very worthy cause. Any and all amounts are greatly appreciated. 
Please spread the word!There are so many charities in the world, and I'm sure many of you are flooded with opportunities to donate your time and money. It can be really overwhelming. 
I have chosen this particular charity because:
  1.  I know Julie Veloo. She is an extraordinary, driven, compassionate, and dedicated woman. Her foundation is strategic, transparent, and highly effective in a community with minimal recognition or support. 
  2. I know Baggii and Saraa. They are wonderful people and concerned first and foremost with the health and safety of their animals. 
  3. I know myself. I chase adventure like a fat kid after cheesecake. I considered joining the Mongol Derby (a similar horse trek), or spending June on a horse trekking tour, but I decided on this ride because, in addition to the extraordinary experience, it directly contributes to the benefit and welfare of an unfairly disadvantaged population. Mongolia is a country undergoing changes at a breakneck pace. Millionaires are being made everyday, but many people fall through the cracks. As a researcher, I live and work here. My friends are here. My fun is here. But accountability is key, not only in sharing the results of my work, but in contributing to the society at large. I think the Gobi Gallop is a perfect way to combine my love of adventure with my desire to help.

story:
First some words about me

My name is Zivan Tesic. I’ve been training Mix Martle Arts for 10 years. Last year I decided to pursue one of my passion and take a trip to Brazilian Jiu Jitsu in Rio Janeiro. I trained at several places in Rio but during the time that I spent at Fernando Terere’s Acadmy in Ipanema I felt like I was at home. Everybody was so friendly. It was big family within the community. After so many years training martial arts I’ve never seen an atmosphere like the one at Terere’s academy. Now, after returning to Germany, I think it’s time to give something back to the members of the Cantagalo favela. I decided to create this campaign in order to gain a little financial support for Terere Kids Project. The idea behind the campaign is to raise the funds to sponsor the athletes in competitions for an entire year, as well as help to pay for the snack program. Just think, for the cost of one kimono, you could sponsor 5 kids to compete and win a spot at the top of the podium. 

What is the Terere Kids Project?

The Terere Kids Project is a social project founded by 5x World Champion Fernando “Terere” Da Silva. The project is located in Mestre Terere’s gym at the base of the Cantagalo Favela in Ipanema, Rio de Janeiro. The space for the academy was given to Terere free of rent by the government, and the students built the academy by hand alongside Mestre Terere. Since its inauguration in 2012 the academy has been a second home for children from the community that come to learn the Arte Sauve. Donations from abroad allow the project to buy kimonos, pay for competition fees, and provide snacks after the children’s class. 

The mission of the project is to provide kids from the Cantagalo community a safe environment where they can play, grow and learn together. Many favelas in Rio lack the infrastructure and the resources to provide safe alternatives to playing on the street amongst the gangs and drug dealers. Terere himself suffered from drug addiction that halted his career in Jiu Jitsu for close to 10 years. Understanding first hand the perils associated with drug addiction, Terere formed the social project as a means to introduce more kids to Gracie Jiu Jitsu, a sport that he attributes to saving his life. Although he is back on the Jiu Jitsu scene, Terere has stepped away from the competition fervor and instead has opted to use his experiences, both on and off the mats, to help form a new generation of athletes. 

Everyday more kids join the project and start training and competing thanks to the kimono donations and money sent for competition fees. The athletes that are more dedicated to competing have started developing their own curriculums and are learning to market themselves as athletes.

Details about the Project

Terere Kids Projects serves 30-40 kids ranging from ages 3-18. 

The project expenses include:

1.  Snack Program

2.  Children’s kimonos

3.  Tournament Registration fees

4.  Transportation fees (for chaperons)

5.  English program/ art supplies

1.  Snack Program

a.  The project provides a small snack everyday after the kid’s 6pm class. Many of the students from the project do not receive proper education on nutrition and maintaining a healthy diet. One of the goals of the project is to teach our athletes how to maintain a healthy diet in order to excel in the sport.

b.  Cost: R400 (Euro 123)

2.  Children Kimonos

a.  The project relies heavily on kimono donations. It is easy to acquire used A1 kimonos for our older athletes; however, the project has about 15 students under the age of 9 that require kids kimonos. We have a deal with Cascagrossa kimonos were we can acquire kids kimonos at the discounted prices of R100.

b.  Cost: R100 (32 Euros)

3.  Tournament Registration Fees.

a.  Students use donations from abroad to pay for the tournament registration fees. Tournaments allow athletes to gain experience and build a jiu jitsu curriculum. The project has a competition team of 10-15 athletes from ages 6-18.

b.  Cost (10 athletes)

  i.  Monthly: 2,620 (394 Euros)

  ii.  Yearly: 19,855 (10,121 Euro)

4.  Transportation Fees

a.  Transportation fees are used to pay for metro or bus costs to and from competitions. While we generally do not have enough funds to pay for every athlete’s transportation, we try to reimburse the professors and chaperones.

b.  Cost: R7 per athlete (3 Euros)

c.  Cost: R70 10 athletes (22 Euros)

5.  English Program

a.  The project offers and English program to our instructors and our older students. The program is centered on vocabulary for Jiu Jitsu. This has been an extremely effective method since students can practice with international visitors that come to train at the academy. The program requires donations to supply pencils, papers, markers, and other class materials.

b.  Cost: R500  (153 Euros)


"No matter what people tell you, words and ideas can change the world."

Thank you all for supporting my Project.

story:
Our Story

To compare Columbus Preparatory Academy to a children’s book, they are most certainly The Little Engine That Could.  In 2007, CPA was on the brink of closure.  In a state of academic emergency,  the school was plagued by dangerous student behavior, absentee parents and uninspired students.  A change in leadership in 2007 changed everything.  Principal Chad Carr took a gamble and left his home state of Kentucky to accept a new challenge: Show a school what success looks like and show the world that high behavioral and academic expectations can still breed success.   

Mr. Carr created an academic fortress and designed a unique educational program called The Blitz© which is an exciting way to inspire students to learn, to create, to motivate and above all be responsible for their own success in academics.  With The Blitz©, school is not only challenging but fun! Children are motivated to succeed with programs called The Excellent Zone and The Ring of Honor which highlights and publicly honors achievement.  School assemblies have turned into academic pep rallies with rock concert level production and the Blitz pep rallies are instrumental in motivating the students to academic success.  Each year since Mr. Carr's arrival, CPA has climbed higher and higher in pursuit of academic excellence. 

In 2014, the hard work paid off and Columbus Preparatory Academy was ranked the #1 school in the state of Ohio.   Also in 2014, the U.S. Department of Education recognized CPA’s successes and named it a National Blue Ribbon School.  CPA has received the state of Ohio’s highest honor “Excellent with Distinction” 4 years in a row.  With a performance index score of 115.3 out of a possible 120, CPA is the best academically performing school in the state, but it has not met its ultimate goal of scoring a 120.  We need your help to finish the fight and complete the school's mission to be the best school in America-- No Excuses!

The teachers and students at CPA have achieved these amazing feats with fewer resources than most.  In an age when some schools are offering tablets and computers to every single student, CPA still must stretch every dollar.  We have given our students a strong foundation and shown them what it looks like to succeed; now we need extra help in order to stay strong at the next level.    

As a charter school, CPA does not have access to the same level of revenue as traditional schools.  We receive 40% less funding than traditional public schools. CPA has become the highest academically performing school in the state of Ohio with only a fraction of the money received by traditional public schools.  The Fund the Fortress Campaign is an ongoing effort to obtain the funds needed to create a rich learning environment for grades K-12 with the most advanced technologies, amenities and extracurricular and sports programming.  


What We Need & What You Get

What We Need

For the 2015- 2016 school year, it is imperative that we upgrade and increase access to technology.  Next year, the PARCC assessments are requiring our students, as young as 3rd grade, to take multiple assessments on computers.  As the costliest educational tool, we are only currently able to provide the availability of one computer lab and two classroom iPad carts to serve grades K-9.  

Through this campaign, we are asking for your assistance to obtain two additional classroom iPad Mini carts.  The two iPad carts and small administrative costs (less than 10%) for this campaign will cost approximately $35,000.  CPA is able to use an educational discount at Apple and obtain more iPads for less cost.  Our goal of $35,000 reflects this discount. Of course, every donation beyond our goal of $35,000 will be used toward our ultimate goal that every CPA student —from kindergarten to high school—has a personal iPad to enhance their educational experience.  If we are unable to meet our goal, any money raised will go to the purchasing of iPads, as many as we can obtain with the amount received through your generous donations. 

iPad tablet technology is the future of education and is desperately needed to be academically competitive and on par with other districts in central Ohio. CPA students will be able to use this technology to access unlimited digital content including online libraries.  For example, MackinVia is an online platform where teachers can manage eResources and access digital content simultaneously on all students' iPads.  This technology is required for our high school students. High schoolers will access online digital content from the University of Toledo in order to graduate from CPA with not only a high school diploma, but also with an associate’s degree from the University of Toledo at no additional cost.  We have chosen iPads over traditional desktop computers because CPA is lacking space to add computer labs at this time.  Also, iPads minis are less expensive and provide classroom versatility. 

What You Get 

Every donation from $5 to $5,000 is greatly appreciated and you have our sincerest gratitude! Every donor will be acknowledged publicly on CPA’s website. Larger donations will be honored with greater recognition and tickets to CPA's annual Harvest Gala.  For more information regarding donation perks, please view the side bar on the right of this page to select your donation perk.  Also, you may choose to be anonymous or decline a perk. 

As Columbus Preparatory Academy is a nonprofit 501(c)3 organization, your donation may be tax deductible. Any donation received will be accompanied by an electronic acknowledgement with appropriate information to serve as your IRS compliant documentation. Please keep this for your records and provide to your tax preparer if needed.

The Impact

There is no way to measure the impact of your donation.  The potential of iPad use in the classroom is limitless.  By your donation, you are literally placing a world of knowledge into our students’ hands.  They will have access to literature, to scientific videos, academic papers, online collegiate courses and applications to enhance their learning of all subjects including music and foreign languages. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign.  Please, even if you are unable to donate, share this link to your family and friends through social media.   If you know of any other means to obtain technology for the classroom, please reach out to our team.

Larger donations will be honored with greater recognition and tickets to CPA's annual Harvest Gala.  For more information regarding donation perks, please view the side bar on the right of this page to select your donation perk.  Also, you may choose to be anonymous or decline a perk. 



As Columbus Preparatory Academy is a nonprofit 501(c)3 organization, your donation may be tax deductible. Any donation received will be accompanied by an electronic acknowledgement with appropriate information to serve as your IRS compliant documentation. Please keep this for your records and provide to your tax preparer if needed.   The Impact 
There is no way to measure the impact of your donation.  The potential of iPad use in the classroom is limitless.  By your donation, you are literally placing a world of knowledge into our students’ hands.  They will have access to literature, to scientific videos, academic papers, online collegiate courses and applications to enhance their learning of all subjects including music and foreign languages. 

    Other Ways You Can Help Share this campaign.  Please, even if you are unable to donate, share this link to your family and friends through social media.   If you know of any other means to obtain technology for the classroom, please reach out to our team.

story:
The 7.8 earthquake that struck Nepal on Saturday, April 25th, has so far led to over 7,000 deaths, and 500,000 people living in tents. The majority of the displaced victims will never live in a home of their own again. The Nepalese government fears that they are in serious danger of missing the next farming season, which would result in food aid continuing for the next 3 months. 

NEPAL NEEDS YOU.

The “My Dollar For Nepal” Campaign relies on mass numbers to make an impact. We are asking that every individual donates as little as $1 dollar, then spreads the word through social media and word of mouth to his or her friends. The more people that hear about this campaign, the more impact that can be made in Nepal. 

PASHA, a non-profit based in Los Angeles, has medical professionals on the ground in Nepal that are providing care to some of the most affected villages in the region. 100% of the proceeds will go towards continuing this medical support of Nepalese victims. 

Help make a REAL difference. Donate $1 TODAY! 

#MyDollarForNepal

Supporting Organizations:

PASHA at UCLA

Sigma Pi Beta at UCLA

Sigma Pi Sigma Psi at UCLA

Iranian Student Group at UCLA

Embrace at UCLA

Iranian Graduate Student Association at USC

Persian Student Association at CSULB

Pre-Health Club at UCI

Wright 2 Ur Door

story:
Hunniee, Saniya and AJ walked through our doors five years ago. Nearly 10,000 hours of academic and mentoring support later, they continue to walk through our doors. They, and over 150 others since.  

Our goal is to come alongside young people who are facing overwhelming disadvantage and work with them daily, from 1st grade through 12th grade and beyond, until they have defied the odds. Today, 26 kids and teens are walking through our door Monday - Friday, with many more still waiting for the opportunity to participate. 

We need your help to keep this work going. We need your help to expand this work.   

We are ReWritten and we work with young people facing the struggles of single-parent homes, financial hardships and unstable social environments. Through one-on-one tutoring, life ownership development sessions and community engagement we have been able to equip over 150 young people with the tools to carve out their own futures.

Futures undetermined by statistics.

We are located in Colton, CA and work with young people throughout the southern California area. This campaign is about raising the funds needed to sustain our programs and providing the resources needed to equip young people with the tools to thrive. Your investment supports the daily, practical and difficult work of changing the tide: the tide of a culture, the tide of years of history, the tide of a generation in which so many of our young people ARE getting left behind. 


We need $50,000.00 to allow this work to continue in 2015. $50,000.00 will fund a part-time program director (needed to execute daily academic activities), Scantron (an assessment software and tutoring aid for tracking participant academic progress) and 10 new computers for exclusive student use.

Your $50,000.00 will fund the freedom from a predetermined future.


The ultimate perk to investing in ReWritten is the opportunity to change the trajectory of a young person’s life but we do have a few items to give as well. Check them out in our perk section.

If for some reason we do not reach our goal all funds raised will go directly to keeping a part-time program director on staff. It is the relationship with the program directors that lays the foundation for the work of transforming lives, that makes all the difference.

story:
We are 2 creative spirits, enthusiastic about people and traveling, with the desire to explore the world. Creative Seed is our way of sharing our passion and our way of bringing our contribution to the world.



Why

Creativity impacts our way of seeing the world and our ability to find creative solutions. Unfortunately, schools tend to easily overlook the importance of creativity. We believe it is the best form of self-expression and we want to encourage children to express themselves openly and without judgement.

Creative experiences can help children express and cope with their feelings. They also foster personal growth in children by providing opportunities for trying out new ideas, and new ways of thinking and problem-solving. Children become adults who will make a difference in our world with their creative problem-solving skills.

Discovering our creative side shaped our lives and gave us courage to pursue our dreams. Now, we want to create this opportunity for children around the world.

What

The goal of the project is to reach children with difficult backgrounds from 3 different continents and create the right setting for them to explore their creativity and discover other cultures.

How

The Global Citizen programme in AIESEC has helped us find volunteering opportunities and partners for our project.  We want to reach children in Tanzania, Mexico and Romania and spend six weeks in each country organizing creative workshops.

One of us will be going in Tanzania (Andra) and one in Mexico (Mădălina) where we will work with children aged 6-14, adjusting our workshops to the specifics of the local culture. We also wish to explore the local crafting traditions. After completing our six weeks of planting seeds of creativity in Tanzania and Mexico, we’ll come back to Romania. Together we’ll have another six amazing weeks of creative workshops for children in Iaşi adding new cultural elements from our previous experience.

During the workshops we will talk about dreams, friendship, creativity and culture. Together with the children we will experiment with different crafting techniques, learn more about ourselves, explore and share our cultures. Our purpose is to open a door to positive and creative thinking that will lead to stronger individuals and eventually  to a better community.

To sum up the experience we will organize a Craft Gallery with pictures and handcrafts from the project. The purpose of the Gallery will be to show people that creativity has the power to bring change and the potential to connect people and cultures. It is also a nice way to show our appreciation to all of our donors and supporters.

We are committed to make the best out of this experience but for this we need your support. We need 3000 euros to cover the expenses of the project:

  • 300 € materials for the creative workshops

  • 2500 € travel expenses in Tanzania and Mexico

  • 200 € living expenses in Tanzania and Mexico

We have a lot to give to show our appreciation! Except that fact that you will make us happy and bring a lot of smiles to the children that we will work with, you will also be the lucky owners of some really creative handcrafts. Check out our artistic skills.

Andra created a special limited edition of Heartware jewelry with an unique, upcycled approach. It’s a stylish look with steampunk and cyberpunk tendencies.

Madalina  shares with you her impressive quilling works. She creates colorful and inspirational artworks that will brighten your minds and homes.






Our passion for crafting and the desire to explore the world brought us together. We met in AIESEC, an international student organization that offers worldwide volunteering opportunities. We both enjoy working with children and wish to discover other cultures, but most of all, we want to spread our passion and enthusiasm all around the world. 


Andra Fedor

Andra is a social worker and she is studying for her Master’s Degree in Social Science. She enjoys working with people and has a great deal of experience in working with children. She is passionate about crafting and recycling and owns a small business of handmade jewelry.



Mădălina Dîrdără

Mădă is a dynamic, creative and happy person, working towards becoming the best version of herself. Highly motivated and passionate about paper crafting, enthusiastic about people and travelling and with a burning desire to explore the world and bring a change.

story:
The 1989 Generation Initiative was born from our desire to take an active role in redefining the European Project. We are not just another conference or a European youth movement. We are empowering the 89ers to lead the process of EU reform. The 1989 Generation Initiative aims to foster a universal public debate that will generate the very best ideas and policy proposals from all European citizens.

In a fitting article written on the 27th of November 2014 for the Guardian to commemorate the fall of the Berlin Wall, Professor Timothy Garton Ash issued a direct challenge to the next generation of European citizens to assume a leading role in re-articulating the mission of the EU.

The Initiative was launched in March 2015 as a response to this challenge, and is currently an internal student-led organisation of the European Institute, London School of Economics and Political Science. Our team is formed of passionate individuals from over 15 European countries sharing a common belief in the potential of the EU and a strong determination to engage in the process of its reform.


We have received the wholehearted support of Timothy Garton Ash, who has agreed to chair the Grand Roundtable of our Conference on the Redefinition of the European Mission, taking place on the 26th of June, 2015 at the London School of Economics and Political Science. The Conference will produce a declaration containing eight specific proposals for policy reform to be disseminated across key media outlets, EU institutions, national governments and civil society organisations.


We have contacted over 400 university departments, youth organisations and think tanks across all European countries to identify 40 of the brightest representatives of the 1989 Generation to come to London on the 26th of June and discuss their ideas for reform with leading politicians, EU practitioners, academics and representatives of the private sector. Rather than inviting these leaders to give another long speech, we are organising a series of small roundtables that will foster active dialogue between young Europeans and leading figures in Politics, Economics and the private sector. Some of our confirmed speakers for the roundtables (so far!) are: 

  • Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, former French President
  • Jacqueline Minor, Head of the European Commission Representation in UK
  • Neil Kinnock, former leader of the Labour Party and former Vice President of the European Commission
  • Cerstin Gammelin, Süddeutsche Zeitung Europe Editor
  • Fabrizio Saccomanni, Italian Minister of Economy and Finances
  • Karen Smith, Director, European Foreign Policy Unit, LSE IR Department
  • Timothy Garton Ash, Professor of European Studies, Oxford University
  • Christopher Pissarides, Nobel prize winning Economist

To make this a truly pan-European movement, we need your support in order to be able to contribute towards the travel costs of our student delegates and to cover the conference materials, as well as the printing and dissemination costs for our final publication, containing a declaration re-articulating the European mission and the eight policy proposals for reform that the 1989 Generation believes will bring the EU in line with its new mission. 

This is a truly unique opportunity for the brightest young minds in Europe to take ownership of their stake in Europe's future, and we intend our publication to become an authoritative learning resource for all individuals and research groups interested in EU affairs.

Image credits: Valéry Giscard d'Estaing: Baltel/Sipa, Neil Kinnock: Rex Features, Jacqueline Minor: Huffington Post, Christopher Pissarides: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg, Cerstin Gammelin: Suddeutsche Zeitung, Fabrizio Saccomanni: Daniele Scudieri/Imagoeconomica, Karen Smith: LSE, Timothy Garton Ash: DPA

story:
Help WeNAG.org. Help Save Lives.

The Non-riders Awareness Group was conceived as a means to bridge the gap between riders and drivers, through education and awareness:

  • Our founder is a rider, designer and web developer of 15+ years.
  • With more and more riders on the road, motorcycle casualties are on the rise.
  • Your help today, could save lives tomorrow.


What We Need & What You Get

Before the first website, flyer, poster or video is created, we need to complete the task of completing the steps to secure our non-profit status.
With your donation, NAG will provide you with monthly newsletters and a welcome packet.
If we do not reach our entire goal, we plan on continuing with the project in a limited capacity.

The Impact

While law enforcement run limited campaigns on a statewide basis, NAG will affect countless lives year round and worldwide.

A web developer by trade and a rider at heart, our founder has worked with numerous Fortune 500 companies on multi-million projects over the past 15 years.

This project will create a unity between riders, drivers, law enforcement, motorcycle clubs and manufacturers alike to create an environment of mutual understanding, for safer roadways. 


Risks & Challenges

With over 1 billion cars on the road worldwide in multiple countries, it is a monumental task to not only reach them logistically, but compassionately. 
We, at NAG, completely understand the huge task at hand, but we also know that we need to take those first steps and reach that first driver. 
If we reach one driver and save one life, then this project was a success in our eyes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not every one has disposable income to help a non-profit group, no matter how genuine their intentions are and we completely understand, but you can help without even leaving your computer...

  • Use the tools Indiegogo has provided and help spread the word.
  • E-mail your local motorcycle dealerships and send them our info.
  • Reach out to your MC or your friend's MC.

NAG needs you!

story:
Hola! Bienvenidos a Mamemi!

Soy mamá y expatriada. Me encanta leer o inventar cuentos para mis peques, y vivir en un entorno donde se hablan diferentes idiomas es enriquecedor. Por estos dos motivos creé Mamemi.com, una web para escuchar cuentos en muchos idiomas. En Mamemi encontrareis cuentos clásicos y otros inventados por mi, con la inestimable ayuda de la imaginación de mis hijos. Actualmente la web tiene muchos cuentos en 11 idiomas, pero... Sabéis una cosa? ¡Caperucita Roja, el cuento más famoso del mundo, no está en nuestra lista! Es por este motivo por el cual necesito vuestra ayuda, para que me ayudéis a poder publicar "La Caperucita Roja" en muchos idiomas, para que niños de todo el mundo puedan escucharlo, en su idioma y en otros, para que todos nos sintamos iguales dentro de nuestras diferencias. 

Lo que necesito y lo que se obtiene

¿Qué necesito? traductores, leedores, contratar un estudio de sonido, que la ilustradora con la que colaboro dibuje una maravillosa Caperucita... Por eso calculo que el coste de 11 traducciones, contratar 11 leedores, el estudio de sonido que los grabe y monte los archivos y finalmente la ilustración, costaría todo junto 1500 $ .

¿Qué obtendréis a cambio? Suscripciones gratuitas para tener acceso ilimitado a www.mamemi.com, para que podáis guardar vuestros cuentos favoritos en vuestra propia carpeta, para que podáis participar en sorteos especiales... a un precio muy inferior al de la suscripción. Recibir en formato PdF una ilustración de Caperucita personalizada, para que vuestro pequeño compruebe que Caperucita le ha dedicado su "foto".

¿Qué pasará si no logro la meta total? Continuaré buscando fondos, porque los niños necesitan soñar, porqué los niños son nuestro mundo y se merecen escuchar cuentos y despertar su imaginación. ¿Un secreto? Mis pequeños se duermen cada día con un cuento de Mamemi.

Todos los patrocinadores recibirán igualmente el regalo (una suscripción gratuita i un dibujo de nuestra Caperucita dedicado)

El impacto

El proceso de ejecución de un cuento en Mamemi requiere tiempo, paciencia, pasión. Debo encontrar a traductores, gente que tenga buena voz y guste a los niños, un estudio de sonido que grabe y monte el audio preparado para ser escuchado en muchos idiomas, y una ilustración que impacte, que guste, que enamore. ¿Os gustan nuestras ilustraciones? Pues imaginaos una ilustración de Caperucita con este tipo de dibujos ¿Verdad que podría quedar muy chula?

Mamemi empezó como mi proyecto de reinvención. Al abandonar nuestro país de origen, siendo mamá de dos peques traviesos e interactuando con gente de todo el mundo, puedo decir que escuchar el mismo cuento en muchos idiomas hace que los niños comprendan que no todos somos iguales, pero que a todos los niños les gusta escuchar un cuento, pensar, imaginar... porque de eso se trata, de que los peques de casa aprendan a través de su imaginación.

Riesgos y desafíos

No es fácil encontrar traductores en 11 idiomas. Algunos son muy rápidos, otros abandonan a medias, otros te piden un precio exagerado, otros son muy agradecidos. Asimismo sucede con los leedores, y tener un estudio de sonido de confianza es vital. Uno de los mayores retos que tengo ahora es que debo empezar a buscar gente, pero viviendo en otro país, puesto que actualmente estoy viviendo mi segunda expatriación. Tengo ganas, capacidad de trabajo y me gusta hacer el trabajo bien hecho, para dar a los niños un producto de calidad. No os preocupéis, cuando podáis escuchar la Caperucita de mamemi en 11 idiomas, gracias a vuestras contribuciones, os apasionará!

Otras formas en las que podéis ayudar

Vuestras donaciones son muy muy importantes, como lo es también que podais compartir este trabajo en las redes sociales, para ayudar a difundirlo. Estamos en Facebook y en Twitter, como mamemicuentos.

Gracias por interesaros por el proyecto, gracias por ayudarme o por intentarlo. Os prometo un trabajo de calidad, que se transformará en un proyecto divertido. Os animo a escuchar algunos de los cuentos que actualmente hay en www.mamemi.com, para que comprobéis lo bonitos que son.

Sabéis una cosa? ¡Caperucita Roja, el cuento más famoso del mundo, no está en nuestra lista! Es por este motivo por el cual necesito vuestra ayuda, para que me ayudéis a poder publicar "La Caperucita Roja" en muchos idiomas, para que niños de todo el mundo puedan escucharlo, en su idioma y en otros, para que todos nos sintamos iguales dentro de nuestras diferencias.    Lo que necesito y lo que se obtiene ¿Qué necesito? traductores, leedores, contratar un estudio de sonido, que la ilustradora con la que colaboro dibuje una maravillosa Caperucita... Por eso calculo que el coste de 11 traducciones, contratar 11 leedores, el estudio de sonido que los grabe y monte los archivos y finalmente la ilustración, costaría todo junto 1500 $ .
¿Qué obtendréis a cambio? Suscripciones gratuitas para tener acceso ilimitado a www.mamemi.com, para que podáis guardar vuestros cuentos favoritos en vuestra propia carpeta, para que podáis participar en sorteos especiales... a un precio muy inferior al de la suscripción. Recibir en formato PdF una ilustración de Caperucita personalizada, para que vuestro pequeño compruebe que Caperucita le ha dedicado su "foto".
¿Qué pasará si no logro la meta total? Continuaré buscando fondos, porque los niños necesitan soñar, porqué los niños son nuestro mundo y se merecen escuchar cuentos y despertar su imaginación. ¿Un secreto? Mis pequeños se duermen cada día con un cuento de Mamemi.
Todos los patrocinadores recibirán igualmente el regalo (una suscripción gratuita i un dibujo de nuestra Caperucita dedicado)
El impacto
 El proceso de ejecución de un cuento en Mamemi requiere tiempo, paciencia, pasión. Debo encontrar a traductores, gente que tenga buena voz y guste a los niños, un estudio de sonido que grabe y monte el audio preparado para ser escuchado en muchos idiomas, y una ilustración que impacte, que guste, que enamore. ¿Os gustan nuestras ilustraciones? Pues imaginaos una ilustración de Caperucita con este tipo de dibujos ¿Verdad que podría quedar muy chula?
Mamemi empezó como mi proyecto de reinvención. Al abandonar nuestro país de origen, siendo mamá de dos peques traviesos e interactuando con gente de todo el mundo, puedo decir que escuchar el mismo cuento en muchos idiomas hace que los niños comprendan que no todos somos iguales, pero que a todos los niños les gusta escuchar un cuento, pensar, imaginar... porque de eso se trata, de que los peques de casa aprendan a través de su imaginación.
    Riesgos y desafíos No es fácil encontrar traductores en 11 idiomas. Algunos son muy rápidos, otros abandonan a medias, otros te piden un precio exagerado, otros son muy agradecidos. Asimismo sucede con los leedores, y tener un estudio de sonido de confianza es vital. Uno de los mayores retos que tengo ahora es que debo empezar a buscar gente, pero viviendo en otro país, puesto que actualmente estoy viviendo mi segunda expatriación. Tengo ganas, capacidad de trabajo y me gusta hacer el trabajo bien hecho, para dar a los niños un producto de calidad. No os preocupéis, cuando podáis escuchar la Caperucita de mamemi en 11 idiomas, gracias a vuestras contribuciones, os apasionará!
    Otras formas en las que podéis ayudar  Vuestras donaciones son muy muy importantes, como lo es también que podais compartir este trabajo en las redes sociales, para ayudar a difundirlo. Estamos en Facebook y en Twitter, como mamemicuentos.
Gracias por interesaros por el proyecto, gracias por ayudarme o por intentarlo. Os prometo un trabajo de calidad, que se transformará en un proyecto divertido. Os animo a escuchar algunos de los cuentos que actualmente hay en www.mamemi.com, para que comprobéis lo bonitos que son.

story:
Our slogan: DREAM. ACT. MANIFEST. AND SERVE OUR COUNTRY AND MANKIND. 
We are made up of seven smart, sensitive and creative people. Our programmers, Anudeep, Yatharth and Abhie are not satisfied until everything is right while our researchers Surya, Shakthi, Sunit and Meher work continuously until an effective solution is reached. We are the masters of technology and use a lot of electronic devices before anybody told us how to use it. We are fueled by our confidence. Our passion in robotics makes us all winners. After five years in FLL we have learned that the journey is more important than winning. Failures and setbacks are more important than success. We are now involved in various other outreach programs other than FLL like educating the community about robotics. We took great pride in educating the girls in science and robotics. We also host the Jr.FLL competitions where everyone came together to build their dream city.

Contributors will help us greatly. Every fund helps us get closer to our goal of being able to afford this trip. Without contributors, we won't be able to go. The contributors help make all of our greatest dreams come true as going to the Arkansas International Competition is our dream.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $8,650. A majority of this money will be put into the expenses for food, lodging, and flight tickets. A round trip from NJ to Arkansas isn't that cheap and on-campus lodging costs a hefty amount of money as well. It also costs nearly $1,000 just to register for the competition, while we also need money for materials, and for new shirts for our team. We will also use some of the money to further advance our product called KeenTeen, so all the money is going directly to something robotics related and will not be used for our personal purposes.Since money is the cause of our campaign, the perks can't be something expensive. But we will always thank those who help contribute to our cause. Every single dollar counts and helps us get one step closer to reaching our total goal.If we don't reach our goal, we will use as much of our funding towards the competition and be forced to find some other way in order to pay the bill for going to Arkansas. 

The Impact

Our project can improve the lives of teens all over the world. It was designed to help teens improve their school-life balance. Teen years are some of the hardest years for a person. This is because they are starting to become independent from their parents but aren't quite there yet. As teenagers ourselves, we believed that teens need help in order to maintain a good balance and order in their lives. 
Our project is already proven to work. We first started small and pilot tested it on ourselves. We maintained a log of us using it for over two months. After advice from our experts, we began to spread the project and gave it to kids ranging throughout the teenager years as well as teens of both genders. This is so we don't see one-sided results and so we can try with a varied group of people and receive as best results as possible. 
You can see the first, basic version of our project at : http://green-bots.com/KeenTeen/ 
Learn more about our product in a simple video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YxqyOkT5cQQ

Risks & Challenges

Doing a project like this and funding needed for a trip, well more of a journey for us, there is basically nothing that can go wrong. We organized everything such as the trip, project, robot, etc.  The only problem was the money. And with the proper funding, our dream will be fulfilled. We want the nation to be talking about KeenTeen and FLL, and we won't be able to do it without YOUR help!

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways to help besides donating. You could create and awareness of having a school-life balance and sharing KeenTeen with your friends and family. We would also like to inspire children with FLL, just like we did. 
  • You can also follow us on Facebook: http://bit.ly/greenbots2014fb
  • Twitter: http://bit.ly/greenbots2014twit
  • Instagram: http://bit.ly/greenbots2014gram
  • YouTube Channel: http://bit.ly/greenbots2014yt
  • Visit our website: green-bots.com
T-Shirts will only be shipped to US and Canada. Sorry!
